"Masama ba akong tao?"70,000 ang ipinakulong34,000 ang tinorture3,200 ang pinapatayMahigit P300 billion ang ninakaw(Amnesty International, PCGG)Inaasahan ko, at the very least, isa lang 'tong effort to humanize the Marcoses like Downfall. Kaso hindi, ano rin bang ineexpect ko sa walang hiyang direktor na 'to, pinapalabas na para bang taumbayan pa ang masama, na parang hindi inalipin ng kanilang pamilya ang Pilipinas nang mahigit dalawampu't taon (at sa ngayo'y patuloy pa rin), minaliit ang rebolusyon bilang isang pulitikal na agenda ng mga Aquino, at hindi bilang isang makamasang kilusan na nagpabagsak ng diktadurya. Nakakatakot lang talaga yung huling chapter, kasi sa bawat isang makakakita sa katarantaduhang pinapalabas nito, may limang mauuto at maniniwala sa 'totoong kasaysayang' pinaparatang ni Yap, ng mga Marcos, ng mga bumubura at bumabaluktot sa ating kasaysayan - madaling makita ang appeal nito sa masa, napakadaling ipalimot at mabago ang ating pananaw sa pamilya ng isang diktador.Ang pinakamasahol pa ay, ordinaryong mamamayan pa ang ginamit (ang mga kasambahay at PSC) para sa pagpapalaganap ng propagandang Marcos - para lamang sabihing si Imee pala yung "Maid in Malacanang" (no fucking way they did this). Hanggang ngayon, ginagamit at inaabuso pa rin ng parehong Marcos at Duterte ang taumbayan para sa sari-sariling pulitikal na layunin.Iniisip ko bago 'to panoorin na "Baka bawi naman 'to sa visuals at technical aspects" kaso hindi, ang gimmicky ng long takes, inconsistent yung audio, hindi maayos yung pagpalit from comedy (na hindi rin naman nakakatawa) to drama, ang uncomfortable ng blockings, at ang artificial ng acting ng lahat ng gumanap, high school play lang ang peg.Kahit ganito, naging matagumpay ang pelikula sa nais nitong gawin: hugasan ang pangalan at krimen ng mga Marcos, napa-upo ba naman si Bonget sa palasyo. Pero kahit anong pagbaluktot ang gawin nila sa kasaysayan, kitang kita ngayong ika-39 anibersaryo ng EDSA na tayo pa rin ang may hawak ng kasaysayan, hangga't may hindi nakakalimot, hindi ito mabubura o mapapalitan.1/2 star para sa Traydor na Pag-Ibig ni Marion Aunor, ang ganda ng kanta, pero bakit naman dito ka napunta.Putangina mo Darryl Yap, putangina ng mga Marcos, at putangina ng mga DuterteNever Again, Never Forget!

There really is the sense that Daryll Yap, the director and writer, was only really interested in telling one minute moment of this dark but important part of Philippine history. Historically distorted films have marred history for decades now. Certain movies like Argo, Braveheart, Pocahontas, and Patton had their fair share of twisting history in exchange for spectacle. Even movie juggernauts like Lawrence of Arabia or Titanic have been lambasted because they portray actual events. The difference between those films and this is that they have been created with cinematic accuracies that provide enjoyment to the audience.In the eyes of the filmmakers, what matters most is if the movie generates income, even if it's executed poorly story-wise and technicality-wise.Maid in MalacaÃ±ang, despite its well-divided 10-chapter plot, is a mixture of unnecessary inconsistencies shown in a very cheap spectacle style. Inconsistent shots that tried to execute long takes, like in 1917 or Birdman, but the character blockings and setup make it more annoying than pleasing. Cheap sets used to represent the MalacaÃ±an Palace (The grandest mansion in the Philippines) looked like a huge village home full of creaks and poor paints. Mixing in 21st Century Gen-z dialogues to add humor that doesn't work well. And line delivery seemed like the actors tried to portray their roles because they were asked to and did not practice well.But I got to say, it takes a lot of heart and brains to really watch this one.Because to me, who has watched a good chunk of films, especially award-winning ones, made this film more annoying than enjoyable even if you don't bother comparing it to actual history. I know we are not always gunning for our movies to be "world-class" because filmmaking is still a business, and sales are more important because it generates money. Maid in MalacaÃ±ang is definitely a tad below the low-class filmmaking because the whole movie felt like it was done in a rush, like a school project. Fresh from the success of winning the Philippines' 2022 Presidential elections through their endless propaganda and trolling, Darryl Yap brings us his latest pessimus opus: the fictionalized retelling of the end of Marcos family's dictatorship, focusing on their last three days in MalacaÃ±ang Palace before their exile in Hawaii following the People Power Revolution in 1986.In the film, Cristine Reyes play the fictionalized version of Imee Marcos, who returns to the Philippines after she is summoned by his father, a fictional, mild-mannered version of Ferdinand Marcos (played by Cesar Montano). Upon returning to the film's cheap-looking version of Malacanang, the fictional version of Imee Marcos learns about a failed assassination plot against their family. All throughout the film's excessively long running time, the fictional version of the Marcos family face betrayal of several high-ranking officials, including several Palace staff, food shortages, plus fear and anxiety from the growing number of the "mindless" crowds joining the EDSA revolution. After ten excruciating chapters and 105 wasted minutes, the family, upon the persuasion of the fictional version of Imee, decides to leave the Palace, with the help of m0therfvcking senator Robin Padilla as Gen. Fabian Ver, the Chief of Staff of the AFP under the Marcos Administration. The film ends with people storming the Palace, looting and destroying its premises.Penned and directed by Yap, with the real Imee Marcos serving as the film's creative producer, this propaganda film is actually not the worst Filipino film of 2022 for me (that recognition still belongs to the Claudine Barretto revenge drama "Deception"). But this is definitely the most boring local film from last year. The film opens with a text saying the following: " Ang pelikulang ito ay naglalaman ng mga tunay na kaganapan, sa gitna ng kasaysayan, sa gilid ng kaguluhan, sa likod ng media, na ngayo'y ihaharap sa Bayan." Early on, it already conditions the viewers' minds that what they're about to see is based on a true story. It even used real life footage and clips from the time of the EDSA revolution to make it feel more "real." There's even a voice-over, claiming that Cory Aquino herself was advocating for the public's civil disobedience. We all know how it's going to end, with Marcoses as mere victims of fate and tragedy. Nothing is surprisng anymore. In short, their version of the truth, so it's predictable from the get-go. Kuwento niyo yan, eh.On top of this, the forced comedy makes it even more painful to watch. Can you imagine, the actual "maids" in the movie are the ones that make it more cringy, acting like some chorus and providing comic relief (which all failed). Karla Estrada and Beverly Sarmiento in particular, are both excruciating to watch and listen to. It feels more like a series of Vincentiments skit with bigger names, stitched together to form a film. It also looks like one. It's cheap. It's boring. It's always loud (lots of shouting, as usual). It's very dependent on stirring controversy. Very Darryl Yap.Right from its early scenes, the film's main focus is on the fictionalized version Imee Marcos, making it feel like she's the hero of the story. It's actually pretty confusing, because I remember the real Imee Marcos saying before that she was "too young" when she heard about Martial Law, but here, she's portrayed as a full-grown, fierce and intelligent woman, which we all know are all made up, just like her claim that she is "one of the first female graduates from an Ivy League School -- Princeton University, graduating with honors."And as expected, it paints Ferdinand Marcos as a naive and innocent victim who trusted the wrong people, and the entire family as sad victims. Boohoo. "Palagi lang mabait! Yan, yan yung ginamit nila para mapagbagsak ka. Sobrang tiwala mo sa kanila," said the fictional version of Imee. They did get one detail right though: that young Bong-bong is a party animal, as proven by their massive private video collection obtained by the media, including the infamous "We Are The World" video during his birthday celebration on board the presidential yacht Ang Pangulo.To make matters worse, all the scenes lack tension. They all feel dull, despite how loud the characters shout their lines. The only thing that adds emotions to its scenes is its manipulative and overbearing music. The cinematography employs long shots which, instead of giving the film an authentic feel, makes it look more boring. The performances only add up to the film's blandness, like Ruffa Gutierrez's performance, who looks like she doesn't know any other facial expressions. She's like Jennifer Coolidge, but in a very bad way. You don't know whether she's about to laugh, about to cry, or she's just constipated. The only good decision that this film had is having Cristine Reyes playing the improved, cinematic version of Imee.It's packed with lies after lies, that it is so hard to keep track."Galit na galit sila dahil hindi tayo nanggaling sa elitistang angkan. Galit na galit sila dahil probinsyano lang tayo. Galit na galit sila dahil mahal tayo ng mga tao. Pero hindi ko magawang magalit sa kanila," says the sadboi ex-President in the movie. And I'm not even going to dig further in that scene featuring Giselle Sanchez's portrayal of Cory Aquino playing mahjong with nuns, which has been debunked by the Carmelite sisters themselves.Long, loud, lame and lifeless, this fictionalized, propagandist film from Viva Films and Darryl Yap is nothing more than a disgusting attempt to whitewash the crimes and atrocities under the Marcos dictatorship, and to suck-up to the current administration.The design is very Darryl Yap.

Finally got to see the year's most controversial film! (Currently ranks as the 3rd highest grossing Filipino film* of all-time...as well as the fourth lowest rated film on all of Letterboxd right now.)I think Yap is just too stupid and lazy for this film to be *truly* offensive; as it is, it just plays out as the sort of propaganda whose only goal is to preach to the converted. The Marcoses are depicted as paragons of virtue, unfairly maligned by the ignorant (and jealous) activists/media who've always despised them. There's never any mention as to WHY these activists are so angry--no menton of the thousands of victims of the dictatorship. No, Ferdinand Marcos's only crime (according to this) is that he loved his country too much.I'd like to be charitable--one could defend this by saying that, since this film is only from the perspective of the Marcoses and their staff, that of course the result will be hero-worship...that in fact, he's making a critical view of him by showing how brainwashed his inner circle was....except Yap can't even do that, as he inserts newsreel footage and chapter headings that all promise he's showing us "the TRUE story" of the PPP. And the ending--Cory Aquino's lone appearance, gambling with nuns and heartlessly ordering the Marcos's exile--completely scraps that possibility (as it depicts Aquino as a monster, and it's also a scene no one in the Marcos family witnesses--it's all Yap.)That said: on a formal level, the film is really interesting. The average shot length is about 3 minutes each, and they're not lazy stationary ones; Yap will start a scene outside the palace, then go indoors, up the stairs, into different rooms, with dialogue from multiple actors, all without a cut. I don't quite know why he's doing that, but it's a really neat touch, as most of the film is comprised of conversations, and I'm always a sucker for shooting those at a distance with shots as long as possible--it's the best way to capture performance, imo. And the odd music cues (it starts with an 80s dance version of an OPM classic "Nosi Balasi"), random interjections of humor (from the maids), and odd bookends of scenes (a maid ends her Big Speech to the palace staff by asking one for a candy bar), it's all very interesting...yet totally at odds with the rest of the film which is blunt and brutal.*Thatâ€™s what Wikipedia says, but Iâ€™ve learned that the box office figures for this were almost certainly inflated artificially.
